title: Meta Is Getting Rid of CrowdTangle — and Its Replacement Isn't As Transparent or Accessible - Proof News
snippet: This article quotes Fabio Giglietto, an associate professor of internet studies at the University of Urbino, regarding Meta's MCL. He discusses the limitations of the MCL compared to CrowdTangle, particularly regarding data exporting restrictions, which impacts his work on the Vera AI EU disinformation research project.
description: The article discusses Meta's replacement of CrowdTangle with MCL and quotes Fabio Giglietto, an associate professor of internet studies at the University of Urbino, regarding the limitations of the MCL, especially its impact on his disinformation research within the Vera AI EU project.

title: Cracking the code: social data access and the DSA's impact on disinformation research
snippet: This article, part of the PROMPT series, is co-authored by Massimo Terenzi and Fabio Giglietto. It discusses the impact of the Digital Services Act (DSA) on social media research, particularly in the context of disinformation. It highlights both the opportunities and limitations of the DSA in providing researchers with access to platform data.
description: This article, co-authored by Fabio Giglietto, explores the implications of the Digital Services Act on social media research and disinformation studies, examining both opportunities and limitations for researchers.

title: Facebook accidentally gave misinformation about misinformation to researchers
snippet: The Independent covers how a social media researcher from the University of Urbino, Fabio Giglietto, revealed that Facebook’s data to researchers was incomplete, including only about half of U.S. users.
description: The article from The Independent discusses how Fabio Giglietto, a social media researcher from the University of Urbino, found that Facebook provided incomplete data to researchers regarding misinformation on its platform.

title: Facebook has been giving misinformation researchers incomplete data
snippet: The article reports that Fabio Giglietto, associate professor at the University of Urbino, was the first to discover that Facebook was providing flawed and incomplete interaction data to misinformation researchers by comparing it with the publicly released 'Widely Viewed Content Report.'
description: The Engadget article reports that Fabio Giglietto, an associate professor at the University of Urbino, discovered that Facebook provided flawed and incomplete interaction data to misinformation researchers.

title: How to Detect a Disinformation Campaign - Media Ecosystems Analysis Group
snippet: Fabio Giglietto is interviewed regarding his research on how actors respond to social media platforms' attempts to crack down on coordinated behavior, specifically in the context of COVID-19 mis- and disinformation in Italy. He discusses the importance of analyzing large-scale data sets to figure out and mitigate bad activity online and explains that coordination isn't necessarily an indicator of negative activity.
description: Fabio Giglietto is interviewed about his research on coordinated behavior and disinformation related to COVID-19 on social media platforms, specifically in the Italian context. title: Coordinated Link Sharing Behavior as a Signal to Surface Sources of Problematic Information on Facebook | Request PDF - ResearchGate
snippet: This ResearchGate entry discusses Fabio Giglietto's work (Giglietto et al. 2020) on coordinated link-sharing behavior (CLSB) as a signal to surface sources of problematic information on Facebook. title: Integrating Large Language Models in Political Discourse Studies on Social Media: Challenges of Validating an LLMs-in-the-loop Pipeline | Sociologica
snippet: Fabio Giglietto is listed as an Associate Professor of Internet Studies at the University of Urbino Carlo Bo, co-authoring a paper on integrating Large Language Models (LLMs) into research workflows for studying political content on social media. The paper discusses a validation protocol for LLM-integrated research, addressing the versatility, granularity, and limitations of LLMs in uncovering narratives. It focuses on challenges in validating a pipeline that classifies political links, clusters them by similarity, and generates descriptive labels, aiming to guide social scientists in employing LLM-based methodologies for political content analysis on social media. Published: 2024-10-30.
description: Fabio Giglietto is listed as an Associate Professor of Internet Studies at the University of Urbino Carlo Bo, co-authoring a paper on integrating Large Language Models (LLMs) into research workflows for studying political content on social media, published in October 2024.

title: PROMPT_whitepaper_The State of Social Media Research APIs & Tools in the Digital Service Act Era - Zenodo
snippet: Fabio Giglietto, along with Massimo Terenzi, authored a white paper from the University of Urbino Carlo Bo, analyzing how the European Union’s Digital Services Act (DSA) is transforming data access for platform research. It draws on existing literature and testing of research APIs/tools from platforms like Meta, YouTube, and TikTok. The paper focuses on Article 40.12, which mandates access to publicly available data, and examines how Very Large Online Platforms (VLOPs) are implementing these requirements, identifying gaps, challenges, and potential solutions. Published: 2024-12-19.
description: Fabio Giglietto co-authored a white paper from the University of Urbino Carlo Bo analyzing the impact of the Digital Services Act (DSA) on data access for platform research, focusing on how VLOPs are implementing Article 40.12 regarding publicly available data.
